name: WhatsApp
earlyDays: App that would show statuses to show for other people like "On the flight to Munich, send email instead of calling me."
pivot: Users started using it to ping each other with statuses like, “I woke up late,” or “I’m on my way.” At some point it sort of became instant messaging.

name: Youtube
earlyDays: Dating website for single people to make videos introducing themselves and saying what they were looking.
pivot: Despite offering to pay women $20 to upload videos of themselves to YouTube, nobody came forward. So they decided to remove the "dating" part and allow all types of videos.

name: Slack
earlyDays: Browser-based massively multiplayer online game called Glitch.
pivot: Glitch has not attracted an audience large enough to sustain itself." The next best idea they had was to productize and market an internal communications tool that they had built to run Glitch.

name: Instagram
earlyDays: A mobile app called Burbn that let you: check in to locations, make plans, earn points, post pictures, and much more.
pivot: They wanted to focus on being really good at one thing. So they basically cut everything in the Burbn app except for its photo, comment, and like capabilities

name: Twitter
pivot: Apple released iTunes that took all the podcasting market. Odeo realized the danger, and they started holding official hackathons to search for new products; one of them became Twitter.

name: Shopify
earlyDays: Snowdevil, an online store for snowboarding equipment.
pivot: Dissatisfied with the existing e-commerce products on the market, Lütke, instead built his own.

name: Netflix
earlyDays: Online DVD rental store sent by mail.
pivot: Netflix had considered offering movies online, but there were speeds and bandwith problem in mid-2000. After discovering YouTube, and witnessing how popular streaming services, they introduced video on demand via internet.

name: Yelp
earlyDays: Email-based referral network to ask friends for place recommendation.
pivot: Users were not answering requests for referrals, but were using the "Real Reviews" feature, which allowed them to write reviews unsolicited.

name: Nintendo
pivot: Nintendo experimented in other areas of business like: taxi company, hotel chain, TV network, instant rice; but none of them were succesful. Then they tried to focus on video games.
